name: Lecrae
description:
'''Lecrae Devaughn Moore''' (born October 9, 1979) is an American [[Christian rapper]], singer-songwriter, actor, and [[Record producer|recording producer]] and [[Music executive|executive]]. Since having begun his career in 2004, he has released ten studio albums and four mixtapes as a solo artist, as well as recording with the hip-hop collective [[116 (hip-hop group)|116]], which he co-founded. 

Lecrae's first two studio albums, ''[[Real Talk (Lecrae album)|Real Talk]]'' (2004) and ''[[After the Music Stops]]'' (2006), were both released independently and met with critical praise. His third, ''[[Rebel (Lecrae album)|Rebel]]'' (2008), became the first Christian hip-hop album to peak atop the [[Top Gospel Albums|''Billboard'' Top Gospel Albums]], and his first to enter the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. After the release of his fourth album, ''[[Rehab (Lecrae album)|Rehab]]'' (2010), Lecrae began attracting mainstream attention following his performance at the 2011 [[Black Entertainment Television|BET]] Hip Hop Awards Cypher, and his guest appearance on [[Statik Selektah]]'s single "[[Population Control (album)|Live and Let Live]]" that same year. His sixth album, ''[[Gravity (Lecrae album)|Gravity]]'' (2012), and has been called the most important album in Christian hip hop history by [[Rapzilla]] and ''[[Atlanta Daily World]]''. Along with continued critical praise, it peaked at number three on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and made Lecrae the first hip hop artist to win in the category of [[Grammy Award for Best Gospel Album|Best Gospel Album]] â€” at the [[55th Annual Grammy Awards]]. His seventh album, ''[[Anomaly (Lecrae album)|Anomaly]]'' (2014), became his first to debut atop the ''Billboard'' 200, as well as the first album to peak both the ''Billboard'' 200 and Top Gospel Album charts simultaneously. 

In May 2016, Lecrae signed with [[Columbia Records]]. He released his third mixtape, ''[[Church Clothes 3]]'' (2016), his eighth album, ''[[All Things Work Together]]'' (2017), and his collaborative album with American record producer [[Zaytoven]], ''[[Let the Trap Say Amen]]'' (2018). He left Columbia in early 2020, and released his tenth album, ''[[Restoration (Lecrae album)|Restoration]]'', in August of that year.

He has co-founded three media entities: the record label [[Reach Records]] in 2004, the now-defunct non-profit organization ReachLife Ministries in 2007, and the film production studio 3 Strand Films in 2019.

Lecrae received nominations for Artist of the Year at the [[43rd GMA Dove Awards|43rd]], [[44th GMA Dove Awards|44th]], 45th, and [[46th GMA Dove Awards|46th]] [[GMA Dove Award]]s, the last of which he won, and for [[BET Award for Best Gospel Artist|Best Gospel Artist]] at the [[BET Awards 2013|2013]] and [[BET Awards 2015|2015 BET Awards]], the latter of which he won, a first for a rap artist. Lecrae's filmography includes a role in the television film ''A Cross to Bear'' (2012) and brief roles in the comedy film ''[[Believe Me (film)|Believe Me]]'' (2014), crime film ''[[Superfly (2018 film)|Superfly]]'' (2018), and Christian drama film ''[[Breakthrough (2019 film)|Breakthrough]]'' (2019). Lecrae has presented on and written about [[Race relations in the United States|racial tension]] and [[Racism in the United States|injustice]] in the United States as well as advocated for the preservation of responsibility and fatherhood values among men in the United States. In 2013, he partnered with [[Dwyane Wade]] and [[Joshua DuBois]] in the multimedia initiative ''This Is Fatherhood'' as part of the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama administration]]'s Fatherhood and Mentoring Initiative, and in 2020 during the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] worked with Love Beyond Walls to distribute hand-washing stations and food to homeless people in [[Atlanta]].
